intro: Sisyrinchium flavidum, commonly known as the yellow gaura, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that consist of both ray and disk flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky areas, and it thrives in full sun. Its bright yellow flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies. Sisyrinchium flavidum is often used in native plant gardens due to its ornamental value and low maintenance requirements.
